study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a case of biotinidase deficiency in a neonate and evaluate the effects of biotin supplementation on clinical outcomes.
results_summary: Biotin supplementation resolved severe infections, seizures, and skin manifestations in a neonate with biotinidase deficiency, demonstrating its therapeutic efficacy in this condition.
population_specificity: A neonate presenting with seizures, immunodeficiency-like symptoms, and biotinidase deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a biotin-conjugated prodrug (CPT-SS-FFEYp-Biotin) in enhancing tumor-targeted delivery and therapeutic efficacy of camptothecin while reducing side effects.
results_summary: The study found that CPT-SS-FFEYp-Biotin improved tumor cell uptake via biotin receptor recognition, enhanced drug release via ALP and GSH responsiveness, and demonstrated higher efficacy and safety compared to free CPT in both cellular and in vivo models.
population_specificity: Tumor cells (in vitro) and animal models (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical presentation, diagnosis, and treatment efficacy of biotin in an infant with holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency (HLCSD), primarily presenting with respiratory symptoms.
results_summary: Oral biotin treatment achieved good clinical efficacy in resolving metabolic acidosis and respiratory symptoms in the infant with HLCSD, as evidenced by improved blood gas analysis and symptom resolution.
population_specificity: A 1-year and 4-month-old Chinese male infant with HLCSD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer potential of curcumin derivatives, including one modified with biotin (5d), by assessing their cytotoxicity against A549 cells.
results_summary: The biotin-modified curcumin derivative (5d) exhibited stronger cytotoxicity (2.25 μmol/L) against A549 cells than both curcumin and the positive control drug Doxorubicin (3.99 μmol/L), making it a promising candidate for further investigation.
population_specificity: In vitro study using A549 human lung adenocarcinoma cells.
effective_dosage: Not specified (tested at 2.25 μmol/L concentration in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the sex-specific effects and toxicity thresholds of biotin (Vitamin B7) in germ-free mosquito larvae.
results_summary: The study found that biotin had a toxic effect at high concentrations, with male larvae being more sensitive than females. The toxicity impacted the adult sex ratio, favoring female emergence.
population_specificity: Aedes aegypti mosquito larvae (germ-free and gnotobiotic).
effective_dosage: Varying biotin doses (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a highly sensitive and specific electrochemical biosensor using tetrahedral DNA nanostructures (TDNs) and biotin-streptavidin interactions for detecting low-abundance circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA).
results_summary: The biosensor demonstrated high sensitivity (detecting as few as 60 ctDNA molecules in 100 μl) and excellent specificity (single mismatch discrimination), effectively identifying ctDNA even in complex matrices like serum. The method also showed versatility in detecting ctDNA with various mutation sites.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on in vitro detection of ctDNA).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (biotin used as a signal amplification component, not as a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how intravenous exosomes affect metabolic pathways, including biotin metabolism, in cynomolgus monkeys.
results_summary: The study found that exosomes influenced biotin metabolism pathways by day 14, suggesting a potential role in metabolic regulation, though direct effects on biotin itself were not detailed.
population_specificity: Cynomolgus monkeys

study_goal: The study aimed to elucidate the effect and underlying mechanism of Pirfenidone (PFD) on smoke inhalation lung injury (SILI) in rats, not Biotin (Vitamin B7).
results_summary: The study found that PFD had a significant protective effect on SILI by inhibiting oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis via the NF-κB signaling pathway. It did not investigate Biotin (Vitamin B7).
population_specificity: Rats with smoke inhalation lung injury (SILI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a nanocomposite containing PEGylated biotin (PB) for targeted drug delivery and synergistic photothermal-chemotherapy in breast cancer treatment.
results_summary: The nanocomposite demonstrated high efficacy in targeted drug delivery, photothermal conversion, and inducing cytotoxicity, apoptosis, and tumor regression in breast cancer models, with minimal systemic toxicity.
population_specificity: Human breast cancer cells (MCF-7), mouse mammary gland adenocarcinoma cells (4T1), and 4T1-Luc tumor-bearing mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the latest publications on bitter orange's role in supporting the reduction of excess body weight and its additional health benefits.
results_summary: The study found that bitter orange has antioxidant and anti-ulcer properties and supports weight reduction, though the extent of its efficacy was not detailed. It was grouped among supplements with beneficial effects for obesity treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity population inferred).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between biotinidase deficiency (BD) genotypes and biochemical phenotypes, including the prevalence of variants and their correlation with partial or profound deficiency.
results_summary: The study identified 302 patients with BD, revealing 20 different variants (3 novel) and 31 genotypes, with specific variants significantly associated with either profound or partial deficiency. The most common variants were c.410G>A, c.1270G>C, and c.38_44delGCGGCTGinsTCC, showing distinct genotype-phenotype correlations.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with biotinidase deficiency in a single center in the eastern region of Türkiye, including cases detected via neonatal screening, family screening, or clinical symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic applications of sweet and bitter oranges, focusing on their bioactive ingredients and potential uses in functional foods and medicine.
results_summary: Bitter orange was found to be more effective for anti-osteoporotic products and treating intestinal dysbiosis compared to sweet orange, which was better for anti-diabetic, anti-obesity, and hypocholesterolemic applications. The study also highlighted the valorization of citrus bio-wastes for therapeutic and functional food uses.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a supplement containing bitter orange, grapefruit, and olive extracts in reducing cardiovascular risk in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in cardiovascular risk markers, including flow-mediated vasodilation, blood pressure, lipid profile, oxidative stress, and inflammation biomarkers, but no significant changes in anthropometric variables or quality of life.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of bitter orange as an anxiolytic treatment for sexual performance anxiety.
results_summary: The study suggests bitter orange has anxiolytic properties that may help with sexual performance anxiety, but no specific efficacy data or controlled trials are provided. The evidence is based on general anxiolytic effects rather than direct outcomes for SPA.
population_specificity: Individuals with sexual performance anxiety (general, no specific subgroup detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of aromatherapy using Citrus aurantium blossom essential oil on premenstrual syndrome (PMS) symptoms in university students.
results_summary: The study found that aromatherapy with Citrus aurantium blossom significantly improved overall PMS symptoms, particularly psychological symptoms, in the first and second months of intervention. However, no significant effects were observed on physical symptoms or social function.
population_specificity: 62 university students with premenstrual syndrome.
effective_dosage: 0.5% Citrus aurantium blossom essential oil via inhalation during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.
study_duration: Two months (intervention administered during the luteal phase of each menstrual cycle).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the cardiovascular (stimulatory) effects of bitter orange extract containing 49-mg p-synephrine in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in electrocardiograms, heart rates, systolic blood pressure, blood chemistries, or blood cell counts. A small decrease in diastolic blood pressure (4.5 mmHg) occurred at 60 minutes in the p-synephrine group, with no adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: 18 healthy subjects (nine men and nine women)
study_duration: Single dose with measurements up to 8 hours

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate bitter orange extract (p-synephrine) as a non-stimulatory thermogenic agent for weight management and energy metabolism.
results_summary: The study identified bitter orange extract as a non-stimulatory thermogenic agent that can assist in weight management without adverse cardiovascular effects, particularly when combined with other extracts and flavonoids.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on thermogenic agents).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to consolidate safety and efficacy data on bitter orange (Citrus aurantium) through a systematic review of clinical trials, expert opinions, and historical data.
results_summary: The study compiled evidence on bitter orange's pharmacology, adverse effects, and dosing but did not highlight definitive efficacy outcomes. It provided a comprehensive safety profile, including potential interactions and toxicology.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of available literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of dietary supplements, including bitter orange, in the management of hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that bitter orange was consistently associated with increasing blood pressure, indicating potential adverse effects for hypertensive patients. It was grouped with other supplements that may elevate blood pressure rather than provide benefits.
population_specificity: General population, particularly individuals with hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of bitter orange extract (p-synephrine) alone or in combination with other ingredients, focusing on its effects on metabolic rate, energy expenditure, and weight loss.
results_summary: The study found that bitter orange extract (p-synephrine) did not produce significant adverse effects on heart rate, blood pressure, or other health markers. It modestly increased resting metabolic rate and energy expenditure, with slight weight loss observed over 6-12 weeks.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese subjects (approximately 50% of participants), with some consuming caffeine alongside p-synephrine.
effective_dosage: p-Synephrine (10-53 mg/day), caffeine (132-528 mg/day) in combination studies.
interactions: Caffeine was commonly consumed alongside p-synephrine in studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the thermogenic effects of p-synephrine alone and in combination with flavonoids naringin and hesperidin on resting metabolic rate (RMR) and cardiovascular parameters.
results_summary: The study found that p-synephrine alone increased RMR by 65 kcal, while combinations with naringin and hesperidin further enhanced this effect (up to 183 kcal). No changes in heart rate, blood pressure, or self-reported symptoms were observed.
population_specificity: 10 subjects per treatment group (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: 50 mg p-synephrine alone; combinations included 600 mg naringin and 100 mg or 1000 mg hesperidin.
study_duration: Single-dose intervention (effects measured at 75 minutes post-ingestion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of an acute dose of p-synephrine (from bitter orange) on substrate oxidation during prolonged, constant-intensity exercise.
results_summary: p-Synephrine increased whole-body fat oxidation and reduced carbohydrate oxidation during exercise, though the effect size was small. Energy expenditure remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 14 healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize documented case reports of heart-related problems associated with dietary supplements, including bitter orange.
results_summary: The study identified bitter orange as one of the dietary supplements linked to heart-related problems, though specific adverse effects were not detailed in the abstract. The "Toxic Table" was created to highlight potential risks associated with such supplements.
population_specificity: Individuals consuming dietary supplements, including bitter orange, as reported in PubMed case reports (1966 to April 2016).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the metabolic, lipolytic, and cardiovascular effects of p-synephrine (Bitter orange extract) alone and combined with caffeine during resistance exercise.
results_summary: Supplementation with p-synephrine (S) and p-synephrine plus caffeine (SCF) increased lipolysis at rest and elevated VO₂ during exercise, with SCF showing the highest glucose response. Serum glycerol levels were significantly elevated in S and SCF treatments.
population_specificity: 12 healthy men
effective_dosage: 100 mg p-synephrine (S), 100 mg p-synephrine + 100 mg caffeine (SCF)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cardiovascular effects of a dietary supplement containing caffeine, bitter orange extract (p-synephrine), and green tea extract in mildly overweight individuals.
results_summary: The study found no effects of the dietary supplement on heart rate, blood pressure, or mean arterial pressure. A small but significant decrease in resting respiratory exchange ratio was observed in low caffeine users, suggesting increased fat oxidation.
population_specificity: Mildly overweight individuals (14 females, 9 males; age 24.7 ±7.4 yrs, BMI: 26.6 ±3.8).
effective_dosage: 13 mg p-synephrine and 176 mg caffeine per capsule, taken with each of three meals.
study_duration: Two days (one day for each treatment arm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine acute hematological and mood perception responses to p-synephrine (from Bitter orange) alone and in combination with caffeine during quiet sitting.
results_summary: The study found that 103-mg p-synephrine did not negatively impact acute blood parameters or produce stimulant-like mood effects, while caffeine-containing supplements increased feelings of attention, energy, and vigor. Triglycerides and very low-density lipoproteins decreased significantly with p-synephrine alone.
population_specificity: 16 subjects (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: 103-mg p-synephrine alone; combinations included 233-mg caffeine + 104-mg p-synephrine and 337-mg caffeine + 46-mg p-synephrine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a commercial extract of Black Chokeberry (Aronox®) could reduce oxidative/nitrative stress and hemostasis changes in plasma from breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that Black Chokeberry extract significantly reduced oxidative/nitrative stress and hemostasis changes in plasma from breast cancer patients after surgery and chemotherapy phases, suggesting potential benefits in mitigating thrombosis risk.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients (before/after surgery and during chemotherapy with doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the health benefits of black chokeberry supplementation, focusing on its effects on inflammation, oxidative stress, and gut microbiome.
results_summary: The study found that black chokeberry positively reduces inflammation, oxidative stress, and improves intestinal microflora, though the extent of changes varied depending on multiple variables. The compounds in black chokeberry were concluded to play a key role in maintaining systemic balance.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a commercial Black Chokeberry extract (Aronox®) on thiol levels and antioxidative enzyme activity in plasma from breast cancer patients at different treatment phases.
results_summary: The Aronia extract significantly reduced thiol levels in plasma from breast cancer patients across all tested groups but did not significantly modify antioxidative enzyme activity. The results suggest a beneficial effect on thiol concentration in plasma.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients (before/after surgery, during chemotherapy) and healthy subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of black chokeberry extract on oxidative stress, glucose intolerance, and hyperlipidemia in rats with induced metabolic syndrome-like disturbances.
results_summary: The study found that black chokeberry extract improved antioxidant status, normalized lipid peroxidation, lowered cholesterol, and exhibited hypoglycemic effects, likely due to reduced mucosal disaccharidase activity.
population_specificity: Rats with induced oxidative stress, glucose intolerance, and hyperlipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of lyophilized black chokeberry extract on pro-inflammatory cytokines, hepcidin, and markers of iron metabolism in young football players.
results_summary: Supplementation with black chokeberry extract significantly improved IL-6, IL-10 levels, and total antioxidant capacity (TAC) after maximal aerobic effort, indicating enhanced antioxidant status and protective changes in inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: 22 male football players (mean age 19.96 ± 0.56 years).
effective_dosage: 6 g of lyophilized black chokeberry extract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of anthocyanin-rich Black Chokeberry on cognitive function in relation to lifestyle-related factors.
results_summary: The abstract suggests beneficial effects of dietary anthocyanins on cognition in older adults and children, but does not specify results for Black Chokeberry.
population_specificity: Older adults and children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cytotoxic effects of Black Cohosh triterpenoids on multiple myeloma cell lines and identify the most potent compounds.
results_summary: The study identified cimigenol-type triterpenoids as the most active constituents against multiple myeloma cells, with 25-O-methylcimigenol-3-O-α-L-arabinopyranoside showing the highest potency. The arabinose moiety and methyl group at C-25 were found to enhance cytotoxic activity.
population_specificity: Multiple myeloma cell lines (NCI-H929, OPM-2, U266).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Black Cohosh on cell viability and the expression of ER-α, PR, and BRCA1 in breast cancer cell lines, both alone and in combination with hormones and antihormones.
results_summary: Black Cohosh significantly reduced ER-α and BRCA1 expression in a concentration-dependent manner, with notable decreases in cell proliferation. Co-treatment with estrogen (E2) further amplified these effects, suggesting anti-cancer properties.
population_specificity: T-47D and MCF-7 breast cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Black Cohosh (Cimicifuga racemosa) with evening primrose oil in reducing hot flashes and improving quality of life in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Black Cohosh significantly reduced the severity and number of hot flashes and improved quality of life scores more effectively than evening primrose oil. Both treatments improved MENQOL scores, but Black Cohosh showed superior improvement.
population_specificity: 80 postmenopausal women experiencing hot flashes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether black cohosh (iCR) alone or in combination with St. John's wort (iCR + HP) could safely and effectively treat climacteric symptoms in breast cancer survivors receiving endocrine therapy.
results_summary: The study found that most breast cancer survivors experienced reduced climacteric symptoms with iCR/iCR + HP, with no estrogen-like effects on the breast or hormones. Additionally, recurrence-free survival rates were significantly higher in users compared to non-users, supported by antiproliferative and anti-invasive effects of iCR in breast cancer cells.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors receiving endocrine therapy, including those on tamoxifen.
effective_dosage: Higher iCR doses or iCR + HP were suggested to counter tamoxifen interference (specific amounts not stated).
interactions: None mentioned for iCR and HP with endocrine therapies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of black cohosh and estrogen on thermoregulation in ovariectomized rats.
results_summary: Black cohosh and estradiol both improved abnormal thermoregulation in ovariectomized rats, with black cohosh more effective at reducing core body temperature and estradiol more effective at reducing tail-skin temperature.
population_specificity: Female Sprague-Dawley rats (8 weeks old, ovariectomized)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of SWIR-HSI and chemometric analysis to discriminate between true black cohosh and adulterated commercial products.
results_summary: The study found that 7 out of 36 commercial products were identified as true black cohosh using SVM-DA modeling, while 29 showed adulteration. UHPLC-MS analysis confirmed six products as authentic black cohosh based on marker compounds.
population_specificity: Commercial black cohosh products and raw material samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanisms of standardized isopropanolic black cohosh on submandibular gland function in ovariectomized rats, comparing it to estrogen therapy.
results_summary: Black cohosh improved submandibular gland function by protecting M1 receptor expression and reducing oral dryness, though its mechanism differed from estrogen, which affected M1, M3, and AQP5 expression. Both treatments similarly improved daily water consumption and vasodilation.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized (OVX) rats as a model for menopausal women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of Black Cohosh-induced autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) with hepatotoxicity.
results_summary: The study found that Black Cohosh may induce autoimmune hepatitis and hepatotoxicity, representing the third documented case of such an adverse effect. The evidence on its safety and benefits remains conflicting.
population_specificity: 69-year-old female

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of black cohosh extract on the proliferation and apoptosis of Ishikawa human endometrial adenocarcinoma cells, and its potential role in suppressing estrogen-induced cell proliferation.
results_summary: Black cohosh decreased Ishikawa cell proliferation in a dose-dependent manner and suppressed estrogen-induced cell proliferation more effectively than progesterone. It also induced apoptosis in these cells.
population_specificity: Ishikawa human endometrial adenocarcinoma cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term effects of black cohosh on glucose and lipid metabolism in a rat model of post-menopause.
results_summary: Black cohosh significantly reduced body weight gain, fat mass, serum triglycerides, hepatic fat accumulation, and improved insulin resistance and glucose intolerance in ovariectomized rats, with no detected hepatotoxicity.
population_specificity: Adult female Sprague-Dawley rats (post-menopausal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether black cohosh improves objective and subjective sleep quality in early postmenopausal women with sleep complaints.
results_summary: Black cohosh significantly improved sleep efficiency, reduced wake after sleep onset duration, and tended to enhance subjective sleep quality. It also improved vasomotor and physical quality-of-life domains without reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Early postmenopausal women aged 45-60 years with sleep disturbances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if exogenous treatments (salicylic acid, jasmonic acid, ethylene, or mechanical wounding) could increase the levels of actein and deoxyactein in Black cohosh rhizomes to reduce harvesting pressure.
results_summary: Salicylic acid treatment significantly increased actein and deoxyactein levels in Black cohosh rhizomes, suggesting its role in regulating triterpene glycoside synthesis. This could help meet supplement industry demands while conserving Black cohosh and dependent species.
population_specificity: Black cohosh rhizomes (plant study, no human participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exogenous treatments applied, but exact concentrations/frequencies not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of isopropanolic black cohosh (Remifemin) in alleviating menopausal symptoms in women with uterine fibroids versus other therapies.
results_summary: Isopropanolic black cohosh was found to effectively relieve menopausal symptoms in women with uterine fibroids without increasing fibroid size, making it a preferable treatment option.
population_specificity: Women with uterine fibroids experiencing menopausal symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Black Cohosh affects estrogen receptor-alpha (ERα) and progesterone receptor (PR) levels in breast cancer cells, and its potential hormonal mechanisms.
results_summary: Black Cohosh (5-100 µM) reduced ERα and PR protein levels in T-47D breast cancer cells and decreased cell viability. Combined treatment with hormones/antihormones further downregulated ERα and PR.
population_specificity: ER (+) and PR-A/B (+) T-47D breast cancer cells (in vitro study).
interactions: Combined with estradiol, ICI 182,780, and Tamoxifen.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of black cohosh on purified mammary and placental 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 1 (17βHSD1) activity compared to testosterone and tibolone.
results_summary: Black cohosh had no impact on the activity of purified mammary and placental 17βHSD1, unlike testosterone and tibolone metabolites, which inhibited the enzyme to varying degrees. The study concluded that black cohosh, along with the other compounds, displayed a beneficial effect on local mammary estrogen metabolism by not affecting or decreasing local estradiol exposure.
population_specificity: Purified enzymes from human mammary gland and placenta.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Black Cohosh in treating early menopausal symptoms using the Greene climacteric scale (GCS).
results_summary: Black Cohosh significantly reduced the GCS total score and all subscale scores (vasomotor, psychiatric, physical, and sexual symptoms) at both 4 and 8 weeks compared to placebo, with no reported side effects.
population_specificity: 84 early post-menopausal participants with GCS scores of 15 to 42 in Tehran, Iran.
effective_dosage: 6.5 mg of dried extract of Black Cohosh roots daily (one tablet per day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the evidence on the efficacy and safety of herbal preparations, including Black Cohosh, for managing menopausal symptoms.
results_summary: The abstract states that Black Cohosh is commonly used for menopausal symptoms but benefits only a limited proportion of women, without providing specific efficacy data. No adverse effects or safety concerns are mentioned.
population_specificity: Women experiencing menopausal symptoms (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Black Cohosh (Actaea racemosa) for managing menopausal symptoms, addressing discrepancies in previous reviews.
results_summary: The study found a standardized mean difference of 0.385 in favor of Black Cohosh (p < 0.0001), indicating significant efficacy for menopausal symptom relief. The authors criticized a recent Cochrane review for neglecting substantial evidence supporting Black Cohosh's benefits.
population_specificity: Menopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of black cohosh on vasomotor symptoms (hot flashes) in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in the severity and number of hot flashes in the black cohosh group compared to placebo at weeks 4 and 8, suggesting it is effective for relieving menopausal vasomotor symptoms.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (n=84)
effective_dosage: One tablet per day (specific dosage not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Black Cohosh extracts (BCE) on the immune system in mice, particularly focusing on immune cell populations and responses.
results_summary: BCE exposure in mice showed minimal immune effects overall, with dose-related decreases in thymic and splenic cell populations, increased cytotoxic T cell activity, and no significant impact on humoral immune responses or innate immunity.
population_specificity: Female B6C3F1/N mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Black Cohosh (Cimicifuga racemosa) extracts could effectively alleviate climacteric complaints without the adverse estrogenic effects associated with hormone replacement therapy (HRT).
results_summary: The study found that Black Cohosh extract (CR BNO 1055) reduced major climacteric complaints as effectively as conjugated estrogens and more than placebo, without estrogenic effects on mammary glands or the uterus. European preparations were effective, while some US preparations were ineffective, likely due to incorrect dosing or adulteration.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women and ovariectomized rats.
effective_dosage: Not specified (but mentions "low doses" were effective).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of black cohosh in women with or at risk of breast cancer, particularly its estrogenic activity and impact on menopausal symptoms.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between black cohosh and increased breast cancer risk, with some evidence suggesting reduced risk in postmenopausal women. Efficacy for hot flashes was inconsistent, showing benefits compared to baseline but not placebo, and no significant impact on hormone levels or estrogen-responsive tissues was observed.
population_specificity: Women with or at risk of breast cancer, including postmenopausal women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effectiveness and safety of black cohosh for treating menopausal symptoms in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between black cohosh and placebo in reducing hot flushes or menopausal symptom scores. Hormone therapy was more effective than black cohosh, but evidence on safety and other outcomes was inconclusive due to poor reporting and heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal and postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the toxicity and safety profile of Black Cohosh extracts in rodents, focusing on hematological, organ-specific, and developmental effects.
results_summary: The study found dose-dependent hematological changes, including non-regenerative macrocytic anemia and increased micronucleated red blood cells in both mice and rats, with more severe effects in mice. Thymus and liver toxicity were observed in rats, and puberty was delayed at higher doses, but no estrogenic or anti-estrogenic activity was detected.
population_specificity: Female B6C3F1/N mice and Wistar Han rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Black Cohosh (Cimicifuga racemosa) on c-Fos protein expression in hypothalamic nuclei of ovariectomized rats to understand its potential therapeutic mechanisms for menopausal symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that Black Cohosh increased c-Fos-positive cell densities in hypothalamic nuclei of ovariectomized rats, similar to estrogen, suggesting it may help alleviate menopausal symptoms by acting on these brain regions. The effects were temperature-dependent, with the most significant changes observed at extreme temperatures.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized rats (animal model for menopause).
effective_dosage: Not specified (isopropanol extract of Cimicifuga racemosa used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the vasorelaxant effects of black cohosh extract (BcEx) and its potential mechanisms of action in rat aorta.
results_summary: BcEx induced two phases of relaxation in rat aorta: a rapid, endothelium-dependent phase mediated by the NO/cGMP pathway and a slower, endothelium-independent phase involving inhibition of calcium influx via potassium channels. The findings suggest potential vascular health benefits of black cohosh.
population_specificity: Isolated rat aorta

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the chemopreventive potential of black cohosh, specifically its effect on mammary tumor incidence in Sprague-Dawley rats.
results_summary: Black cohosh reduced the incidence of mammary adenocarcinomas in a dose-dependent manner, with higher doses (35.7 and 7.14 mg/kg) showing significant reductions. It also decreased Ki-67 and cyclin D1 protein expression in fibroadenomas.
population_specificity: Female Sprague-Dawley rats aged 56 weeks at study start.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the pharmacological mechanisms and short-term toxicological effects of black cohosh on female Sprague-Dawley rats, focusing on gene activity and lipid content.
results_summary: Black cohosh downregulated mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation genes, upregulated phospholipid biosynthesis and remodeling pathways, and exhibited antiproliferative effects similar to known anticancer compounds. It also altered lipid metabolism, reducing serum free fatty acids and triglycerides while increasing liver lipid content.
population_specificity: Female Sprague-Dawley rats
effective_dosage: 35.7 mg/kg of black cohosh extract enriched in triterpene glycosides (27%)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether black cohosh affects mammographic breast density in postmenopausal women compared to hormone therapies and placebo.
results_summary: Black cohosh did not significantly influence mammographic breast density after six months of treatment, unlike hormone therapies (E2/NETA and tibolone), which showed significant increases. The study confirmed black cohosh's lack of effect on breast density using digitized quantification.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether black cohosh extracts inhibit the formation of active tamoxifen metabolites, potentially reducing its clinical efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that a 75% ethanolic extract of black cohosh significantly inhibited the formation of active tamoxifen metabolites and competitively inhibited CYP3A4 and CYP2D6 enzymes. The results suggest potential interference with tamoxifen's efficacy when co-administered with black cohosh.
population_specificity: Women experiencing hot flashes as a side effect of tamoxifen therapy.
interactions: Potential interaction with tamoxifen via CYP3A4 and CYP2D6 inhibition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hepatotoxicity risk of Cimicifuga racemosa (Black Cohosh) rhizome extract and its safety profile in long-term users.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of hepatotoxicity in 107 women using Black Cohosh extract for over 12 months, contradicting earlier EMEA reports of suspected liver damage. Clinical and blood examinations showed no signs of hepatic disease or worsening of pre-existing conditions.
population_specificity: 107 women using Black Cohosh extract continuously for over 12 months, primarily for menopause-related disorders.

study_goal: To develop analytical methods to distinguish black cohosh from adulterant species of Actaea in commercial products.
results_summary: HPLC and LC-MS fingerprints identified distinct phytochemical patterns, with cimifugin and cimiracemoside F as key markers to differentiate black cohosh from Asian Actaea species. Formononetin was absent in all tested species.
population_specificity: Not applicable (plant samples, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of black cohosh in reducing menopause-related vasomotor symptoms compared to conjugated equine estradiol/medroxyprogesterone acetate and placebo.
results_summary: The study failed to show benefit for black cohosh in reducing menopause-related vasomotor symptoms. No significant improvement was observed compared to placebo or the active control.
population_specificity: Menopausal women experiencing vasomotor symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and tolerability of black cohosh extract in alleviating menopausal symptoms in breast cancer patients undergoing tamoxifen therapy.
results_summary: Black cohosh significantly reduced overall menopausal symptoms, particularly hot flashes, sweating, sleep problems, and anxiety, but had no effect on urogenital or musculoskeletal complaints. Adverse events were reported but not linked to the medication, and tolerability was rated as very good or good by 90% of patients.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients (n=50) receiving tamoxifen, most of whom had undergone surgery, radiation therapy (87%), and approximately 50% chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 1-4 tablets (2.5 mg) of isopropanolic black cohosh extract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of reversible complete heart block linked to black cohosh and review its known side effect profile.
results_summary: The study found a case of reversible complete heart block in a woman taking black cohosh and reviewed its association with liver toxicity and other side effects.
population_specificity: A woman who recently began taking a black cohosh supplement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether black cohosh (specifically the isopropanolic extract, iCR) adversely affects liver function in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of five clinical trials found no significant adverse effects of iCR on liver function markers (aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase, and γ-glutamyltranspeptidase) after 3-6 months of treatment. The results showed no differences between placebo-controlled and other trials.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal and postmenopausal women aged 40-60 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of Black Cohosh on cytochrome P450 enzymes, specifically Cyp3a11, and its potential herb-drug interactions mediated by pregnane X receptor (PXR).
results_summary: Black Cohosh induced liver-specific Cyp3a11 expression in mice in a dose- and time-dependent manner, mediated by mouse PXR but not human PXR, suggesting herb-drug interactions in humans may not involve human PXR and CYP3A4.
population_specificity: Wild-type, Pxr-null, PXR-humanized, and double transgenic CYP3A4/hPXR mice.
interactions: Potential herb-drug interactions via cytochrome P450 induction, but human PXR was not activated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Black Cohosh (Cimicifuga racemosa) and estrogen on osteoporotic fracture healing in ovariectomized rats.
results_summary: Black Cohosh promoted metaphyseal callus formation and supported fracture healing, though its biomechanical effects were less pronounced than estrogen. The study suggested that longer application might reveal its full potential.
population_specificity: Twelve-week-old ovariectomized or sham-operated rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on the efficacy of herbal preparations containing black cohosh for treating menopausal symptoms.
results_summary: Six out of nine randomized placebo-controlled trials showed significant improvement in menopausal symptoms with black cohosh. A combined estimate indicated a 26% improvement in vasomotor symptoms, though with significant heterogeneity between trials.
population_specificity: Menopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if black cohosh extract is superior to placebo in reducing anxiety symptoms related to menopause and to assess its tolerability.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant anxiolytic effect of black cohosh compared to placebo. There was a greater reduction in total GCS scores with placebo, and no significant differences in other secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Women with anxiety disorder due to menopause (n=28).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the maximum tolerated dose of a 75% ethanol extract of black cohosh and assess the pharmacokinetics of 23-epi-26-deoxyactein in menopausal women.
results_summary: The study found no acute toxicity or estrogenic hormone effects, with pharmacokinetic analyses showing dose-proportional increases in 23-epi-26-deoxyactein levels and a short half-life (~2 h). Less than 0.01% of the compound was excreted in urine, and no metabolites were detected.
population_specificity: 15 healthy, menopausal women
effective_dosage: Single doses containing 1.4, 2.8, or 5.6 mg of 23-epi-26-deoxyactein

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of black cohosh compared with placebo for relieving menopausal vasomotor symptoms.
results_summary: Black cohosh did not significantly reduce vasomotor symptoms compared to placebo, showing a 34% reduction versus placebo's 63%. The study found it safe for daily use over 12 months.
population_specificity: Menopausal women experiencing vasomotor symptoms (n = 89).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and potential adverse effects of Black Cohosh, particularly its association with liver damage.
results_summary: The study reported two cases of severe liver injury (submassive necrosis and chronic hepatitis) linked to Black Cohosh use, suggesting caution due to inconsistent therapeutic value and potential risks.
population_specificity: Two patients with liver damage likely related to Black Cohosh use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential hepatotoxic risk of Black Cohosh by analyzing reported cases of liver disease suspected to be linked to its use.
results_summary: The study found little supportive evidence for significant hepatotoxic risk from Black Cohosh, with only 1 out of 69 cases showing possible causality, and confounding variables were prevalent in most cases. The cases were generally poorly documented, with multiple factors complicating causality assessment.
population_specificity: Patients with reported liver disease suspected to be linked to Black Cohosh use.
interactions: Co-medication with synthetic drugs and dietary supplements, including herbal mixtures, was noted as a confounding variable.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the causal relationship between Black Cohosh use and rare hepatotoxicity in patients with liver disease.
results_summary: In eight of nine cases, causality for hepatotoxicity was excluded or deemed unlikely due to alternative diagnoses, missing temporal association, or low-quality data. Only one case showed a possible link to Black Cohosh, but confounding factors like cholelithiasis and fatty liver were present.
population_specificity: Patients with liver disease suspected of hepatotoxicity linked to Black Cohosh use.
effective_dosage: Unknown daily dose (mentioned in one case).
interactions: Comedication with synthetic drugs, herbal, or dietary supplements was reported in five of nine patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a reliable HPTLC method for identifying Black Cohosh (Cimicifuga racemosa) and detecting its common adulterants in the marketplace.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a rapid and practical HPTLC method capable of identifying C. racemosa and detecting adulteration levels as low as 5% with other Cimicifuga species. The method was validated for specificity, stability, precision, and robustness, making it suitable for quality control in manufacturing.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory-based study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the current literature on the benefits of black cohosh for women experiencing climacteric symptoms, focusing on its efficacy and safety.
results_summary: The study found conflicting results regarding black cohosh's efficacy for menopausal symptoms, with methodological flaws such as lack of uniform drug preparation and variable outcome measures. Case studies also suggested potential adverse events that require further investigation.
population_specificity: Women experiencing climacteric (menopausal) symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether there was a causal relationship between Black Cohosh treatment and severe hepatotoxicity in patients with postmenopausal symptoms.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of a causal link between Black Cohosh and the observed liver diseases in the assessed patients, with diagnoses instead pointing to autoimmune and herpetic hepatitis.
population_specificity: Patients with postmenopausal symptoms and suspected hepatotoxicity related to Black Cohosh use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy and safety of Black Cohosh in managing vasomotor symptoms, such as hot flashes, in menopausal women and breast cancer patients.
results_summary: Black Cohosh significantly reduced the frequency or severity of hot flashes in open-label and treatment-controlled trials, but placebo-controlled trials showed contradictory results. Adverse effects were rare (5.4%), mild, and reversible, though serious events like liver damage were reported without clear causality.
population_specificity: Menopausal women and breast cancer patients experiencing vasomotor symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical evidence for or against the efficacy of black cohosh in alleviating menopausal symptoms.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent evidence regarding black cohosh's effect on menopausal symptoms, with no clear demonstration of efficacy, though a beneficial effect for peri-menopausal women could not be excluded. Further rigorous trials were deemed necessary.
population_specificity: Peri- and post-menopausal women (total of 1112 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Black Cohosh (CR BNO 1055 extract) on body weight, fat accumulation, hormone levels, and metabolic markers in ovariectomized rats, comparing them to estrogen treatment.
results_summary: Black Cohosh reduced body weight gain, intra-abdominal fat accumulation, and fasting plasma insulin levels without affecting uterine mass, but had mixed effects on plasma lipids (increased LDL-Ch and decreased TG). It also lowered LH secretion but did not significantly improve glucose tolerance.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized female Sprague-Dawley rats.
effective_dosage: 6.67 g/kg of CR BNO 1055 extract in diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether black cohosh affects the central endogenous opioid system in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Black cohosh had no effect on spontaneous luteinizing hormone pulsatility or estrogen concentrations but showed unexpected suppression of mean luteinizing hormone pulse frequency during naloxone blockade. It also increased mu-opioid receptor binding potential in brain regions involved in emotional and cognitive function.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (n = 6 for LH pulsatility, n = 5 for PET imaging)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Black Cohosh has a direct anabolic effect on osteoblasts and its potential role in preventing postmenopausal bone loss.
results_summary: Black Cohosh did not stimulate osteoblast proliferation but suppressed it at high doses (1000 ng/mL). At 500 ng/mL, it significantly increased bone nodule formation and enhanced gene expression of runx2 and osteocalcin, effects mediated via an estrogen receptor-dependent mechanism.
population_specificity: Mouse MC3T3-E1 preosteoblast cells (in vitro study).
interactions: Interaction noted with ICI 182,780 (selective estrogen receptor antagonist), which abolished the stimulatory effects of Black Cohosh.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Black Cohosh, alone or in combination with other botanicals and soy, on vaginal, endometrial, and reproductive hormone outcomes compared to placebo and hormone therapy.
results_summary: The study found that Black Cohosh, whether used alone or as part of a multibotanical product with or without soy dietary changes, had no significant effects on vaginal epithelium, endometrium, or reproductive hormones. No differences were observed between herbal groups and placebo in vaginal cytology, dryness, menstrual cyclicity, or hormone profiles.
population_specificity: Women aged 45-55 with two or more vasomotor symptoms per day, excluding recent users of hormone therapy or menopausal herbal therapies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of Black Cohosh, specifically investigating potential liver toxicity in women using it for postmenopausal symptoms.
results_summary: The study reported two cases of liver toxicity linked to Black Cohosh use, suggesting potential safety concerns and recommending close monitoring for women taking this herbal remedy.
population_specificity: Women using Black Cohosh for postmenopausal symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which black cohosh extract (BCE) alleviates menopausal symptoms and to explore its potential pathways of action.
results_summary: The study found conflicting results regarding BCE's mechanisms, with one triterpene suppressing cytokine-induced nitric oxide production in brain microglial cells, while the whole BCE extract enhanced this pathway. The efficacy of BCE in alleviating menopausal symptoms was noted, but its absorption and tissue distribution remain unknown.
population_specificity: Not specified (preclinical study involving brain microglial cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the triterpene content of two commercial Black Cohosh preparations and assess their effects on estrogenic markers in serum and breast tissue.
results_summary: One BCE preparation with 2.5% triterpenes relieved menopausal symptoms, with effects reverting post-washout. BCE showed no systemic or breast-specific estrogenic effects.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women
study_duration: 12 weeks of intervention, followed by a 12-week washout

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mode of action and active principles of Black Cohosh, particularly its effects on estrogen receptor-positive human breast cancer cells (MCF-7).
results_summary: The study found that Black Cohosh extract and its purified compounds inhibited cellular proliferation and induced gene expression patterns distinct from estrogen or tamoxifen, showing anti-proliferative, pro-apoptotic, and stress-response effects. Cycloartane-type triterpenoids were identified as active principles.
population_specificity: Estrogen receptor-positive human breast cancer cells (MCF-7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of black cohosh in treating hot flashes and related symptoms in patients with hormone-sensitive cancers, particularly breast and prostate cancer.
results_summary: The study found inconclusive evidence for black cohosh's efficacy in treating hot flashes in breast cancer patients, though it suggested a good safety profile without phytoestrogenic activity and possible antiproliferative effects. Concerns about liver toxicity were noted as inconclusive.
population_specificity: Patients with hormone-sensitive cancers (breast and prostate cancer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ACCX, a compound from Black Cohosh, could block osteoclastogenesis and prevent bone loss induced by RANKL or TNFalpha.
results_summary: ACCX effectively blocked in vitro osteoclastogenesis by inhibiting NF-kappaB and ERK pathways and attenuated TNFalpha-induced bone loss in vivo, suggesting potential as an antiosteoporosis agent.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo models, not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of black cohosh and fluoxetine in treating postmenopausal symptoms, particularly hot flushes, night sweats, and depression.
results_summary: Black cohosh significantly reduced the Kupperman Index and was more effective than fluoxetine in reducing hot flushes and night sweats, with an 85% reduction by the sixth month. Fluoxetine was more effective in improving depression scores compared to black cohosh.
population_specificity: 120 healthy women with menopausal symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of Black Cohosh (iCR) with tibolone in treating climacteric complaints in Chinese menopausal women.
results_summary: Black Cohosh (iCR) showed non-inferior efficacy to tibolone in reducing climacteric symptoms, with a significantly better safety profile, including fewer adverse events and no cases of vaginal bleeding. The benefit-risk balance favored iCR over tibolone.
population_specificity: Chinese women aged 40-60 with climacteric complaints (KMI ≥15).

study_goal: To evaluate the usage pattern, effectiveness, and safety of Black Cohosh alone or in combination with St. John's wort for menopausal symptoms in general clinical practice.
results_summary: Both Black Cohosh monotherapy and its combination with St. John's wort significantly improved menopausal symptoms, with the combination being superior for mood-related symptoms. Adverse events were rare (0.16%) and non-serious.
population_specificity: 6141 women in Germany treated by outpatient gynecologists.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify gene expression alterations induced by a methanolic extract of black cohosh in human breast cancer cells.
results_summary: The extract increased expression of genes related to ER stress, apoptosis, lipid biosynthesis, and Phase 1 metabolism at 6 hours, and decreased expression of cell cycle genes at 24 hours, suggesting potential benefits in breast cancer prevention and therapy.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-453 human breast cancer cells

study_goal: To investigate the effect of black cohosh (iCR) on estrogen biosynthesis in normal breast tissue in vitro.
results_summary: Black cohosh (iCR) decreased local estrogen formation in premenopausal breast tissue at a concentration of 0.1mg/ml. Steroid sulfatase (STS) activity and protein expression were detected in all specimens, with more estrone (E1) produced than estradiol (E2).
population_specificity: Pre- and postmenopausal women undergoing reduction mammoplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of black cohosh in combination with St. John's wort for alleviating climacteric symptoms and its effects on vaginal atrophy, hormone levels, and lipid profiles in peri- or postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The combination of black cohosh and St. John's wort significantly reduced climacteric symptoms (measured by Kupperman Index scores and hot flushes) and improved HDL cholesterol levels compared to placebo. No significant changes were observed in vaginal maturation indices or other hormone levels.
population_specificity: Peri- or postmenopausal women experiencing climacteric symptoms (n=89 initially, 77 completed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-invasive effects of Black Cohosh (iCR) and its major fractions (TTG and CAE) on highly invasive MDA-MB 231 breast cancer cells.
results_summary: iCR suppressed tumor cell invasion by 51.8% at 77.4 µg/ml without affecting cell viability, while TTG and CAE reduced invasion by 34% and 25.5%, respectively, at 5 µg/ml. The study suggests iCR may have chemopreventive potential in postmenopausal hormone replacement therapy.
population_specificity: Highly invasive MDA-MB 231 human breast cancer cells (estrogen receptor-negative).
effective_dosage: iCR at 77.4 µg/ml; TTG and CAE at 5 µg/ml.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an isopropanolic Cimicifuga racemosa extract (iCR) influenced recurrence-free survival in breast cancer patients, including those with estrogen-dependent tumors.
results_summary: The study found that iCR was not associated with an increased risk of breast cancer recurrence and was linked to prolonged disease-free survival, with the iCR group taking 6.5 years to reach the same recurrence proportion as the control group at 2 years. The hazard ratio (0.83) indicated a protractive effect on recurrence rates.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients treated at general, gynecological, and internal facilities in Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Black Cohosh on lipids, fibrinogen, glucose, and insulin in peri- or post-menopausal women experiencing vasomotor symptoms.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in lipid profiles, glucose, insulin, or fibrinogen levels between Black Cohosh-containing therapies and placebo. An increase in fibrinogen was noted in the multibotanical group but was not statistically significant compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Peri- or post-menopausal women aged 45-55 experiencing vasomotor symptoms.
effective_dosage: 160 mg daily (Black Cohosh alone) or 200 mg daily (in multibotanical).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high dose of isopropanolic black cohosh extract (iCR) interacts with low doses of the aromatase inhibitor formestane in a rat model of chemically induced breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that formestane significantly reduced tumor growth and serum estrogen levels, and these effects were not altered by concomitant high-dose black cohosh. The data suggest no concerns about combining aromatase inhibitors with black cohosh in this experimental setting.
population_specificity: Rats with chemically induced breast cancer.
effective_dosage: 60 mg herbal substance per kg body weight (iCR); 3.5 mg or 5.0 mg formestane per animal daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of Black Cohosh, both alone and as part of a multibotanical regimen, for relieving vasomotor symptoms in menopausal and postmenopausal women compared to placebo and hormone therapy.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in vasomotor symptom relief between Black Cohosh (alone or in combination) and placebo at any time point. The herbal interventions showed little potential as effective therapies for these symptoms, with differences of less than 1 symptom per day compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 351 women aged 45-55 years, 52% in menopausal transition and 48% postmenopausal, experiencing at least 2 vasomotor symptoms per day.
effective_dosage: 160 mg daily (Black Cohosh alone); 200 mg daily (as part of multibotanical).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether black cohosh extracts activate the human mu opiate receptor (hMOR) and support its role in alleviating menopausal symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that black cohosh extracts effectively displaced [3H]DAMGO binding to hMOR, acting as a mixed competitive ligand with agonist activity, suggesting a mechanism for its benefits in menopausal symptom relief.
population_specificity: In vitro study using Chinese hamster ovary cells expressing hMOR.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of black cohosh extract (BCE) and genistein on breast cancer cell growth and enzyme activity related to estrogen synthesis.
results_summary: BCE inhibited growth in breast cancer cells at higher doses (50 and 100 µg/ml) and reduced the conversion of oestrone sulphate to oestradiol in both cell lines, while genistein showed mixed effects, stimulating growth in some cells but inhibiting it at high doses.
population_specificity: MCF-7 and MDA-MB-123 breast cancer cells, and human granulosa lutein (GL) cells.
effective_dosage: 50 and 100 µg/ml for BCE; 10 and 50 µM for genistein.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the potential of Black Cohosh as a non-hormonal alternative for managing menopausal symptoms.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Black Cohosh's effects.
population_specificity: Women experiencing menopausal transition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an isopropanolic extract of black cohosh on mammographic breast density and breast epithelial proliferation in postmenopausal women with climacteric symptoms.
results_summary: The study found no increase in mammographic breast density or breast cell proliferation after 6 months of treatment. Adverse events were minor, and no serious safety concerns were identified regarding breast tissue, endometrium, or general health.
population_specificity: Naturally postmenopausal women with climacteric symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the endometrial safety, tolerability, and efficacy of a special Black Cohosh extract (CR BNO 1055) in postmenopausal women with estrogen deficiency symptoms.
results_summary: The study found no cases of endometrial hyperplasia or serious adverse outcomes, a marked decrease in hot flushes, and good overall tolerability with a low dropout rate. Endometrial thickness did not increase, supporting the safety profile of the extract.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with symptoms related to estrogen deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide a comprehensive review of the pharmacological, phytochemical, and therapeutic properties of Black Cohosh (Cimicifuga sp.).
results_summary: The study found that Black Cohosh contains various bioactive compounds and exhibits a wide range of pharmacological effects, including anti-cancer, anti-inflammatory, and anti-microbial properties, but noted a lack of systematic research on many potential compounds.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Black Cohosh in alleviating menopausal symptoms, particularly vasomotor symptoms (VMS) and depression.
results_summary: Some studies reported that Black Cohosh alleviated symptoms like VMS and depression, but it is not currently recommended due to uncertainty about appropriate dose, preparation, and potential safety concerns. Evidence remains inconsistent and limited for other symptoms.
population_specificity: Women experiencing menopausal symptoms, including vasomotor symptoms (hot flushes, night sweats) and psychological symptoms (depression, anxiety).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Black Cohosh as a complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) approach for managing vasomotor symptoms (VMS) in breast cancer patients.
results_summary: The abstract mentions Black Cohosh as one of the CAM approaches for treating VMS in breast cancer patients but notes a lack of solid evidence to guide clinicians in its use. No specific efficacy data for Black Cohosh is provided.
population_specificity: Patients with breast cancer undergoing hormonal treatment, experiencing vasomotor symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical data, safety profile, and justification for using Black Cohosh in alleviating menopausal symptoms and gynecological disorders.
results_summary: The abstract notes that limited data are available on the use of Black Cohosh for alleviating menopausal and gynecological symptoms, but no specific findings are provided.
population_specificity: Women with menopausal symptoms or gynecological disorders (e.g., premenstrual syndrome, dysmenorrhea).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of isopropanolic extract of Cimicifuga Racemosa (iCR) in reducing menopausal symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that iCR was effective in reducing menopausal symptoms, particularly vasomotor symptoms, sleep problems, and irritability, with improvements observed after 1 and 3 months of treatment.
population_specificity: Menopausal women (83 cases receiving iCR and 80 controls receiving no treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of black cohosh for ovulation induction and improving pregnancy rates in women with PCOS-related infertility.
results_summary: Black cohosh improved hormone regulation and endometrial thickness compared to clomiphene citrate (CC), and three RCTs reported improved pregnancy rates when combined with CC. No differences in adverse events were noted, but studies had risk-of-bias concerns.
population_specificity: Women with PCOS-related infertility.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Black Cohosh on HPA-axis-related hormones in humans through randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found significant variability in results across phytonutrients, with no clear conclusion on Black Cohosh's effects on HPA-axis activity. The abstract does not specify Black Cohosh's individual outcomes, only noting general uncertainty.
population_specificity: Human participants in randomized controlled trials (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and safety of a nutraceutical containing Black Cohosh in reducing menopausal symptoms in post-menopausal women.
results_summary: The nutraceutical demonstrated a statistically significant reduction in hot flushes and sweating, effectively improving menopausal symptoms and general health indicators.
population_specificity: Post-menopausal women aged 45-60 years old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Clinical Practice Guidelines (CPGs) to identify recommendations for Natural Health Products (NHPs), including Black Cohosh, in managing menopause-related vasomotor symptoms (VMS).
results_summary: Black Cohosh was included in all five CPGs that mentioned NHPs, but recommendations varied from cautious use to not recommended, with inconsistencies in evidence supporting these recommendations.
population_specificity: Menopausal women experiencing vasomotor symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effectiveness of complementary and alternative medicines, including Black Cohosh, in reducing vasomotor symptoms (VMS) in menopausal populations and cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that combined preparations of Black Cohosh significantly reduced VMS, with moderate to high methodological quality in the systematic reviews and meta-analyses reviewed. However, the evidence levels were not high.
population_specificity: Menopausal populations and cancer patients experiencing vasomotor symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Cimicifuga racemosa extract (CR, Ze 450) and menopausal hormone therapy (MHT) on metabolic parameters, body weight, and menopausal symptoms in symptomatic menopausal women.
results_summary: Both CR and MHT improved menopausal symptoms significantly, but neither treatment altered metabolic serum parameters or body weight over the follow-up period.
population_specificity: Symptomatic menopausal women over 40 years old, with a higher proportion of postmenopausal women in the CR group (83%) compared to the MHT group (55%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Black Cohosh is effective in mitigating anxiety or depression symptoms, particularly in cancer patients, compared to conventional treatments.
results_summary: Black Cohosh was identified as a promising herb for alleviating anxiety or depressive symptoms, with favorable risk-benefit profiles compared to standard treatments, though larger clinical trials are needed for confirmation.
population_specificity: General population (not exclusively cancer patients, but potential relevance noted for them).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the likelihood of drug interactions for various dietary supplements, including Black Cohosh, and provide guidance on their safe use with medications.
results_summary: The study found that Black Cohosh has a low likelihood of drug interactions and, with certain caveats, can safely be taken with most medications.
population_specificity: U.S. adults taking prescription medications concurrently with dietary supplements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential herb-drug interactions involving Black Cohosh, specifically its effects on CES1 and CES2 enzymes.
results_summary: The study found that Black Cohosh may alter systemic exposure to certain drugs metabolized by CES1 or CES2, but specific effects on efficacy or safety were not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract refers to general herb-drug interactions, not a specific human or animal population).
interactions: Potential interactions with drugs metabolized by CES1 or CES2 (e.g., oseltamivir, irinotecan, clopidogrel).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Black Cohosh and other CAM treatments for alleviating menopausal symptoms by reviewing randomized clinical trials, systematic reviews, and meta-analyses.
results_summary: The abstract notes that few well-conducted studies exist on Black Cohosh's efficacy for menopausal symptoms, suggesting limited or inconclusive evidence. It does not provide specific findings on its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Women experiencing menopausal symptoms (e.g., hot flushes, night sweats).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Black Cohosh as a nonhormonal alternative for managing menopausal symptoms compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found no high-quality, consistent evidence that Black Cohosh benefits patients more than placebo for menopausal symptoms.
population_specificity: Women experiencing menopausal symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical effectiveness of Black Cohosh for relieving vasomotor symptoms (VMSs) in postmenopausal women with a uterus.
results_summary: Black Cohosh was found to be more effective than placebo for relieving VMSs, though not significantly better than oral or transdermal estradiol and progestogen (O+P). The study did not report significant adverse effects or discontinuation rates for Black Cohosh.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with a uterus experiencing vasomotor symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Cimicifuga racemosa (Black Cohosh) extracts, particularly for menopausal symptom relief, based on clinical studies conducted over several decades.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of nine placebo-controlled studies confirmed the reliable efficacy of CR-based medicinal products for menopausal symptoms, with 11,073 patients included in the analysis. Safety assessments covered breast, breast cancer, endometrium, and liver health, indicating a favorable safety profile.
population_specificity: Menopausal women (studies conducted in Europe, America, and Asia).
effective_dosage: Not specified (93% of patients received isopropanolic extract iCR).
study_duration: Not specified (studies spanned from the 1950s to 2015).

study_goal: The researchers were examining the potential of Black Cohosh as a non-oestrogen therapy for managing vasomotor symptoms (hot flushes) in menopausal women, particularly those with a breast cancer diagnosis.
results_summary: The abstract suggests Black Cohosh may be among the non-oestrogen options for alleviating hot flushes, but its efficacy is implied to be uncertain ("perhaps"). No specific results or statistical data are provided.
population_specificity: Menopausal women, especially those with a breast cancer diagnosis where hormone therapy is contraindicated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of nonhormonal approaches, including Black Cohosh, for managing menopause-related symptoms compared to hormone therapy.
results_summary: The study found that none of the available botanicals, including Black Cohosh, are as effective as hormone therapy for managing vasomotor symptoms, and data on efficacy and safety are limited.
population_specificity: Women experiencing menopause-related symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety of Black Cohosh and other popular dietary supplements in breastfeeding mothers and their effects on infants.
results_summary: The study found limited evidence supporting the safety of Black Cohosh, particularly among lactating women, and noted a lack of high-quality clinical trials evaluating its effects.
population_specificity: Breastfeeding mothers and their infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the drug metabolism and pharmacokinetic (DMPK) characteristics of Ranunculaceae-derived medicinal compounds, including Black Cohosh, and highlight challenges in optimizing drug development and clinical practice.
results_summary: The abstract mentions concerns about herb-drug interactions involving Black Cohosh but does not provide specific efficacy or safety results. It emphasizes the need for more DMPK studies to understand bioavailability, metabolomics, and interactions.
population_specificity: Not specified
interactions: Herb-drug interactions (specifically with Black Cohosh and goldenseal) are mentioned as a concern.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the mechanisms of herb-drug interactions and discuss pharmacokinetic interactions of Black Cohosh with conventional drugs.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for Black Cohosh but indicates that pharmacokinetic interactions with conventional drugs were reviewed using in vitro, animal in vivo, and clinical studies.
population_specificity: Not specified
interactions: Potential pharmacokinetic interactions with conventional drugs were discussed, but specific interactions for Black Cohosh were not detailed.

study_goal: To determine the effects of Black Cohosh, alone or mixed with other herbals, on hot flushes and at least one other co-occurring symptom during the menopausal transition and early postmenopause.
results_summary: One study of Black Cohosh alone and two studies of Black Cohosh mixed with other herbals showed significant effects on hot flushes and at least one additional symptom. Adverse events were mild to moderate, and women generally tolerated the preparations well.
population_specificity: Women during the menopausal transition and early postmenopause.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the availability and reliability of safety and efficacy information for Black Cohosh and other herbal products on retail websites.
results_summary: The study found that less than 8% of retail sites provided safety information for Black Cohosh, and less than 3% cited scientific literature to support claims. Key safety and efficacy details were largely missing from online sources.
population_specificity: Not specified (general online retail sites)

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of black cohosh extract 40 mg/day for relieving moderate to severe menopausal symptoms and improving quality of life in Thai women.
results_summary: Black cohosh extract 40 mg/day was not superior to placebo in relieving menopausal symptoms or improving quality-of-life scores, though a lower proportion of participants in the treatment group had moderate to severe symptoms (40% vs. 60%, p = 0.174). No serious adverse events or significant changes in liver function tests were reported.
population_specificity: Peri- or postmenopausal Thai women aged at least 40 years with moderate to severe menopausal symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Black Cohosh in managing hot flashes in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study concluded that Black Cohosh should not be used to treat hot flashes in breast cancer survivors, indicating insufficient evidence for its therapeutic efficacy.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors experiencing hot flashes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the frequency of alternative causes in cases of initially suspected herb-induced liver injury (HILI), including Black Cohosh.
results_summary: The study found that 48.5% of initially suspected HILI cases had alternative causes unrelated to the implicated herb, but specific findings on Black Cohosh were not detailed.
population_specificity: Cases of suspected herb-induced liver injury (HILI) from 23 published case series and regulatory assessments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding Black Cohosh (Cimicifugae racemosae) to clomiphene citrate improves ovulation induction and pregnancy rates in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: The study found that combining Black Cohosh with clomiphene citrate significantly improved endometrial thickness, midcycle estradiol and LH levels, mid-luteal progesterone, and clinical pregnancy rates compared to clomiphene citrate alone. Pregnancy rates per cycle were nearly double in the Black Cohosh group (34.8% vs. 17.2%).
population_specificity: Women under 35 years with infertility and PCOS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory effects of Black Cohosh on the metabolic activation of tamoxifen and irinotecan in human liver microsomes.
results_summary: Black Cohosh was found to be the strongest inhibitor among the tested supplements for both CYP450 and carboxyesterase-mediated biotransformation of tamoxifen and irinotecan, respectively, reducing the formation of their active metabolites. The study highlights potential concerns about its interaction with chemotherapy drugs.
population_specificity: Human liver microsomes (in vitro study)
interactions: Inhibits CYP450 and carboxyesterase-mediated pathways for tamoxifen and irinotecan

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential skeletal benefits of Black Cohosh in the context of osteoporosis treatment and prevention.
results_summary: The study found that the skeletal benefit of Black Cohosh is unknown, with no conclusive evidence supporting its efficacy for bone health.
population_specificity: Adults, with no specific subgroup mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the epidemiology, presentation, and diagnosis of herbal hepatotoxicity, including Black Cohosh.
